docs.lead_paragraph: As part of his budget for the coming year, President Clinton will propose expanding Medicaid and Medicare to allow tens of thousands of people with disabilities to retain their health benefits when they return to work, Administration officials say. Under current law, many of these people must, in effect, choose between working and keeping their health insurance coverage. If they take jobs and earn any significant amounts of money, they jeopardize their disability benefits and the insurance coverage they receive through Medicaid and Medicare.

headline.main: CLINTON PROPOSES AID FOR DISABLED RETURNING TO JOBS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, as part of fiscal 1999-2000 budget, will propose expanding Medicaid and Medicare to allow tens of thousands of people with various medical disabilities to retain health benefits when they return to work; proposals would allow those who lose eligibility for Social Security benefits because they return to work to continue Medicare coverage, and those with disabilities to buy Medicaid coverage even if they take jobs and earn income that disqualify them from Supplemental Security Income program; states could allow working individuals with disabilities to buy Medicaid coverage even if they lost eligibility for cash benefits because of medical improvements in conditions; under current law, those with disabilities must in effect choose between working and keeping health insurance coverage; if they work and earn significant amounts of money, they jeopardize disability benefits and insurance coverage they receive through Medicare and Medicaid; graph (M)
docs.snippet: As part of his budget for the coming year, President Clinton will propose expanding Medicaid and Medicare to allow tens of thousands of people with disabilities to retain their health benefits when they return to work, Administration officials say.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals cannot delay or deny emergency room care just because a patient's health insurance plan requires permission before treatment, Government regulators are expected to announce this week. A 1986 law bars hospital emergency rooms from refusing to examine and stabilize patients who cannot pay. Federal officials will use the prohibition against ''dumping'' patients to another hospital to insure immediate care whether or not insurance pays. The provision carries fines up to $50,000 per incident.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Hospitals Cannot Delay Care for Insurance O.K.

docs.abstract: Federal Government regulators will announce that hospitals cannot delay or deny emergency room care just because patients health insurance plan requires permission before treatment; 1986 law bars hospitals from refusing to examine and stabilize patients who cannot pay (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Blow to Hindu Nationalists In State Elections in India Voters in India outraged by rising food prices handed a humiliating defeat to the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party in a series of important state elections. The party lost in Delhi, the district that includes the nation's capital, and in the Hindi heartland state of Rajasthan. In a stunning resurrection, the Congress Party kept a firm hold on power in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, the country's largest. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: The state's first payment does not arrive until April 15, 2000, but the debate has already begun here at the State House over how to spend the state's share of the $206 billion national tobacco settlement. New Jersey and the 45 other states that have signed the agreement are free to spend the money any way they choose. Negotiators have urged states to spend the money on tobacco-control and tobacco-prevention programs, but that has not stopped some New Jersey lawmakers from suggesting that it could be used to address some of the state's other pressing needs.

headline.main: Lighting Up With Ideas For Using Tobacco Money

docs.abstract: Jennifer Preston column on debate among New Jersey lawmakers over how to spend state's $206 billion share of tobacco settlement funds; holds Congress must readdress issue to ensure that steps are taken to prevent future health care costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After failing to slow several years of rising medical costs, health maintenance groups are pushing the costs on to the consumer. Americans can expect to pay 8 to 20 percent more for insurance premiums next year. The rise is the sharpest since the early 1990's and reflects big increases in the prices of prescription drugs, surgical devices and techniques and services to patients outside hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The questions were delivered in brash and burry Glaswegian tones. Who created the television, the telephone, penicillin, the bicycle, pneumatic tires, the breech-loading rifle, beta blockers and Oxford University? The answer was the same in every case: a Scot.

headline.main: Blair Finds Autonomy Only Whets Scots' Appetite

docs.abstract: Scottish Nationalists, campaigning for election to new Scottish Parliament on platform of independence from United Kingdom, are attracting far more support than expected; are seriously challenging Labor Party's traditional domination of Scotland, forcing Prime Min Tony Blair to take bigger role in campaign; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Standing in front of the full-length mirror, the girl fights back tears. Her thighs are too big, her breasts too small and her nose bumpy. Or so this 16-year-old thinks, comparing herself with ''Baywatch'' babes and Victoria's Secret models. To make matters worse, boys never call, and getting undressed for gym is a mortification. But such problems have quick fixes, the magazine ads promise.

headline.main: In Quest for the Perfect Look, More Girls Choose the Scalpel

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE it was created in 1935, Social Security has been the centerpiece of the nation's social contract, an intergenerational commitment to provide at least a subsistence income to the most vulnerable of citizens. The commitment appears as solid as ever. But with Social Security facing long-term financial problems, the means of making good on it are now under serious debate for the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt proposed what would become the most enduring of New Deal legacies.

headline.main: The Nation; Squaring Off, at Last, On Social Security

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Congressional leaders will begin examining troubled Social Security system at two-day White House conference in Dec, kicking off process that could as easily end in partisan gridlock as in historic achievement both parties are hoping for; graph; photo (M)
